detail.content: ﻿           NYU Martial Arts Club - Community                                                                         Martial Arts Club                           Home         Training         Community         Explore                                    The NYU Martial Arts Club is active outside practice, too! Our adventures in New      York City and beyond help enrich us as martial artists and students, and deepen      the bonds of our community. Social events, training retreats, tournaments, and informal      meet ups allow instructors, alumni, senior students, and complete novices to get      to know each other and friendships that will last long after college. Here are a      few perennial favorites:                  Midnight Meander Through Central Park                                     The iconic sights of New York's Central Park are famous around the world, but how      many have seen those same vistas after night falls? Students new to the city always      find the experience especially striking, but even lifelong New Yorkers will see      a side of park they never knew.                          Film and Food                     The club holds social gatherings attended by members, instructors, and alumni several       times each semester in Kimmel. We show martial arts themed movies and always have       plenty of food. Details of upcoming parties can be found on the OrgSync page.                         Summer Training Trip                                     Each summer 20 members of the martial arts club travel to an inn amid the Catskills      Mountains of upstate New York to spend four days living and training together away      from the day to day distractions of regular life.                          Scavenger Hunt                     Running around solving puzzles and getting to know the nooks and crannies of locations       like West Village, Times Square, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum, the Metropolitan Museum,       and many other places besides is great fun, especially if you're feeling competitive.       The club always makes time for a scavenger hunt or two each year.                         Ozawa Tournament                                     Dedicated to karate pioneer Ozawa Osamu, the Ozawa Cup International Karate Tournament      is the largest independent tournament in the world open to all styles of traditional      karate. A delegation of interested students from the NYU Martial Arts Club travels      to Las Vegas each year to attend the tournament. Those who make the journey get      the chance to compete in kata or kumite, and take seminars with world-famous martial      artists. For more information please visit the        Ozawa website .                                                GET CONNECTED                      Email us                       Find us on        Facebook                       Join us on OrgSync                                  FIND OUT MORE                      Home                       Training                       Community                       Explore Martial Arts

Hong Kong Cinema: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Hong Kong Cinema  H72.0321  4 Credits Instructor(s): Zhen Zhang Wednesday 6:00 - 10:00PM Unlike other national cinemas that specifically target audiences of certain geo-political boundaries, hong kong cinema thrives on transnational reception. Hong kong cinema is simultaneously subject to film practices, trends and styles from cinemas all over the world. Symptomatic of hong kong cinema, even the most ‘unique’ genre of the martial arts film has been impacted by different cinemas in the world and witnessed morphing in different social and historical contexts. This course aims toward a history of contemporary hong kong cinema through a study of the genre considered uniquely hong kong: the martial arts film. It also aims to examine the linear history of the martial marts genre within the context of modern hong kong, but also attends to cross-cultural assimilations and penetrations through the study of other genres such as the japanese samurai and american western. Central issues covered by the course include aesthetics of martial arts choreography, national cinema and globalization. Screenings include Hero , A Touch of Zen , The Seven Samurai , Zatoichi , The Wild Bunch , and Kill Bill .    THIS COURSE WILL SATISFY THE CINEMA STUDIES MINOR REQUIREMENT FOR AN INTERNATIONAL CINEMA. The Chinese Martial Arts Film : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        The Chinese Martial Arts Film  H72.0324 4 Credits Instructor(s): Z. Zhen H72.0324.001          Wednesday 12:30 - 4:30PM Instructor: Zhang Zhen                  4 Points. Where and when did the martial arts film emerge? What are the cultural resources this hybrid genre draws from? What kinds of spectatorship has it fostered over the course of eighty years and across national borders? This course addresses these and other related questions through a historical survey of the genre's origins and transformations in the broad landscape of transnational Chinese-language cinema. Screenings include works by key figures such as Zhang Che, King Hu, Bruce Lee, and Tsui Hark, as well as neglected experiments and films associated with their female stars.    THIS COURSE WILL SATISFY THE CINEMA STUDIES MINOR REQUIREMENT FOR AN INTERNATIONAL CINEMA.
